Let it be known to every one of you and to all of the folk-people of Israel that at the behest of and by the authority of Jesus of Nazareth, whom you all crucified, whom God raised from the dead—by using this delegated authority, this fellow stands before you completely well.
That is, “The stone treated with contempt by you, the buildersHas become the principal cornerstone

”There is no security and protection for our natural and spiritual lives in anyone else; the fact of the matter is, there is no other person of impeccable reputation and of authority among the breadth of the varieties of peoples everywhere that the human race has ever produced and put forward as a candidate of such in whom it is absolutely necessary to be rescued from our deplorable spiritual, mental, and physical condition.”

Gawking at the boldness and confidence with which Peter and John were speaking, and floored by the fact that the men were uneducated and untrained, they were flabbergasted and began to notice that they had a close connection with Jesus, having been a part of his life and ministry.
Furthermore, seeing the man standing there in unison with them—the one who had been healed—they couldn’t come up with anything to say against the whole affair.
Ordering them to leave the council chamber, they huddled together

saying, “What should we do about these people, since it certainly has become apparent to everyone who’s visiting or living in Jerusalem that a recognizable miracle has occurred through them, and we can’t deny it?

We can’t let this go on; instead, so that this won’t continue to spread more and more among the folk-people, we’ll threaten them telling them to no longer speak to any person using this authority as the basis for their speaking.”
They summoned them and ordered them not to teach—not even to utter a peep—acting on the basis of Jesus’s authority.
Responding to that order Peter and John told them, “You make the call whether God considers heeding you more than heeding Him the right thing to do;
you see, as far as we’re concerned, we can’t NOT talk about what we’ve seen and heard.”
you see, the man whom this miraculous healing happened to was more than forty years old.
After they were released, they went to their own particular group of people and reported what the chief priests and the councilmen told them.

After they heard this, everyone single-mindedly and in unison raised their voices and directed their words towards God and said, “Master, You who made the sky, the earth, the sea, and everything in it,

who, by means of the Holy Spirit, spoke from the mouth of our ancestor, Your servant David, “Just why, now, did the peopleIn all the various nations become insolent?The folk-people carefully plannedThings which are useless,
for which The kings of the land stood nearby in support,And the rulers were assembled for the same purpose:To oppose the Lord and to oppose His Messiah (Christ).

”The fact is, they actually were assembled in this city for the purpose of opposing Your holy servant Jesus, whom You singled out to be specially chosen and to be given special, supernatural abilities—they being Herod and Pontius Pilate joined by the Gentiles and the Israeli people—
to do what Your situational control and Your well-thought-through plan decided ahead of time would happen.
And now, Lord, take a good, hard look at their threats and grant that Your servant speak Your message time after time with total boldness and confidence,
while at the same time You supernaturally intervene, the intervention resulting in healings, miracles, and supernatural portents occurring through the authority placed in your holy servant Jesus.”

After they were done praying, the place they were gathered was shaken, and everyone there was filled with the Holy Spirit and then began to speak God’s message with boldness and confidence once they left and got on with their daily business.

Now the sizable group of believers was of one heart, mind, and soul, and not a single person was saying that anything that he owned belonged to him exclusively, but instead everything was kept in common between them.

The apostles kept on putting the account of the resurrection of the Lord Jesus out there by means of tremendous miracles, and tremendous grace (i.e., God’s favor and His willingness to act in their behalf and to act through them) was upon them.
In fact, not a person among them was in need. You see, those who owned properties or houses and other buildings kept on selling them and selling them and bringing the proceeds of the sales

to the apostles, placing the proceeds in under their care and ownership. Money, goods, and the like were continuously being distributed to each person in proportion to what a given person happened to need.
Joseph, whom the apostles called Barnabas (which translated means “the epitome of one who fills the role of assistant, advocate, counselor, and encourager”), a clergyman, Cyprian by birth,
being the owner of a field, sold it and gave the money to the apostles, putting it in their custody.
Now a certain man named Ananias sold a piece of property in conjunction with his wife Sapphira
and withheld—appropriated—part of the proceeds, keeping the money for himself (his wife was in on it too) and gave a certain amount to the apostles, placing it under their care and ownership.
Peter told him, “Ananias, how is it that Satan filled your heart causing you to lie in the presence of the Holy Spirit and appropriate some of the sales price from the sale of the property?

While you still had it, wasn’t it yours to keep, and after it was sold, didn’t you have the right to retain control over the proceeds? How did this whole affair get lodged in your heart? You didn’t lie to human beings but to God.”
While Ananias was listening to these words, he dropped dead. An enormous sense of awe and reverence—downright fear—came over all those who were listening.
The older teens and younger men wrapped his body up, carried him out, and buried him.
About three hours went by and his wife came in, unaware of what had happened.
Peter reacted to her entrance, “Tell me: did you sell the property for X amount of dollars?”She said, “Yes, for X dollars.”

Peter said to her, “Why did you two conspire to try to pull a fast one on the Spirit of the Lord? Take a look at the feet of those who buried your husband at the door—and they’re going to carry you out as well.”
She immediately dropped dead alongside his feet. The older teens and younger men came in, checked that she was dead, and took her and buried her next to her husband.
A sense of awe and reverence—downright fear—came upon the entire community of believers and upon those who heard what happened.

Lots of miracles, all kinds of them, occurred among the folk-people. Everyone was on the same page, sharing the same heartfelt passion, meeting in the part of the temple complex called Solomon’s Colonnade.
As far as everyone else was concerned, no one was daring enough to join them, but apart from that, the people thought they were awesome.
More and more kept being added to their party, those who believe in the Lord that is, and not only men but women too,

to the point that they were even bringing out into the streets those with maladies of one sort or another, physical problems that were dragging them down, and placing them upon single-person dining couches and cots, so that when Peter came through he might possibly peer down and check in on any one of them and offer assistance in the form of healing.

Swaths of people in the vicinity of Jerusalem began to gather, bringing those with maladies and those inflicted by dirty, disgusting spirits, all of whom kept on getting healed or otherwise treated for whatever was wrong with them.
The High Priest and all those associated with him (those who belong to the Sadducees sect) were stirred to action by a competitive, passionate zeal,
and they apprehended the apostles and put them in the city jail.
But some time during the night, an angel unlocked the cell door and lead them out, and said,
”Go stand in the temple complex and tell all the short messages—the accounts, stories, sayings, and anecdotes—of this new life in Christ, and do this over and over again.”

Once they heard this, they entered the temple at the crack of dawn and proceeded to teach. Now the chief priest came over while leading his entourage of associates—the Council with all of the councilmen—and they sent word to the city jail to retrieve them.
But when the attendants got there, they didn’t find that they were in the jail, so they turned around, went back, and reported it,

saying, “We found that the city jail was firmly locked down and found the prison guards standing at all of their posts at all of the doors. After they opened the door and let us in, we discovered that no one was there.”
As they heard these words, both the commander of the temple guard and the high priests were perplexed over how this could’ve happened.
Someone showed up and reported to them, “Check this out—the men whom you put in jail are standing in the temple complex teaching the folk-people.”

Then the commander with a party of attendants attached to him proceeded to get them again and take them away—but not by employing violent force, since they were wary and fearful of the people, lest they be pelted with stones.
After they brought them into the council chamber, they were made to stand before the Council. The High Priest questioned them,

”Didn’t I absolutely and emphatically command you not to teach basing your authority to speak on this person? See here now—Jerusalem’s been filled with your teaching, and you want to blame us and have us assume the guilt and consequences for this man’s death.”
Peter and the apostles replied, “We must obey God over obeying people.
God our Father resurrected Jesus, whom you got your grubby hands on and killed, having hung him on a wooden cross-beam.

God exalted this person, this number-one leader and savior, to the position of chief executive officer, to be His right-hand man, to grant a change of heart and of ways to Israel and a forgiveness of sins.
You personally are first-hand witnesses of these affairs and of the Holy Spirit whom God gave to those who obey Him.”
This hit a real sore spot with those who heard this, and they became infuriated and were wanting to kill them.
A Pharisee named Gamaliel, a teacher of the Law of Moses who was well-respected by all the folk-people, got up in the council and ordered the men out for a short while
and said to them, “Men, Israelites, stop, take a look at yourselves, and think for a moment about what you’re about to do to these men.

The fact is, a good while ago, Theudas came to prominence, claiming to be someone special, and four hundred men joined up with him. Everyone who believed in his cause disbanded, and his cause amounted to nothing.

After this, Judas the Galilean came to prominence during the time that the census was being taken, and he led a group of people away in apostasy. And that guy perished too, and everyone who believed in his cause dispersed.

”With that in mind, at this point in time I’m telling you to walk away from these men and leave them alone, because if either the intentions themselves or this cause as a whole happens to be man-made, it will be demolished.
But if it originates from God, you won’t be able to wipe them out—lest it become self-evident that you’re fighting against God.”They were persuaded by him,
and they summoned the men, beat them, and commanded them not to speak based on Jesus’s authority and set them free.
They therefore proceeded to go their way rejoicing after facing the Council because they had been deemed worthy to be dishonored on behalf of Jesus’s authority
and didn’t stop meeting in the temple complex and from house to house every day, teaching and proclaiming the good news—the Gospel—of Christ Jesus.

Now during this timeframe when the number of disciples was expanding, a complaint originated from the Greek-speaking Jews against the native Israeli Jews, that their widows were being overlooked in the Daily Meal Service.
So the twelve summoned the bulk of the disciples and said, “We’re not happy about neglecting the teaching of God’s word by being restaurant waiters.
Look into the matter, comrades, and come up with seven men from among you that it’s been observed and generally agreed are full of spirit and wisdom, whom we might put in charge of this matter.
We, though, will devote ourselves to prayer and to the ministry of the word of God.”

The reasoning put forth was agreeable in the view of the large group assembled, and Stephen, a man full of faith and the Holy Spirit, Philip, Procorus, Nicanor, Timon, Parmenas, and Nicolas, who was a convert to Judaism from Antioch, were chosen.
They stood these men before the apostles, and after they prayed for them, they laid their hands on them.

And the word of God kept on being proclaimed, being received, and producing results, and the number of disciples in Jerusalem continued to grow at a high rate, and a bunch of the priests began to obey by believing in the faith.
Now Stephen, full of grace—God’s favor and His willingness to work through him—and miracle-working capability, began to perform tremendous miracles among the people.
Some people from the synagogue of those who are said to be Freedmen, Cyrenians, Alexandrians, and those from Cilicia and the Roman Province of Asia asserted themselves, arguing with Stephen,
and didn’t have the strength of words to withstand the wisdom and the spirit with which he continuously spoke.
Then they got men to claim that, “While he was speaking, we definitely heard him make a blasphemous remark against the Bible and God,”
and stirred up the folk-people, the councilmen, and the designated teachers and descended on him all of a sudden, apprehended him, and brought him into the Council chamber.
From there, the phony witnesses produced testimony saying, “This man won’t stop uttering remarks against this Holy Place and the Bible.
The fact is, we definitely heard him saying that this Jesus-of-Nazareth-guy will destroy this place and alter the traditions which Moses passed down to us.”
The panel of councilmen fixed their eyes upon him and looked at his face and saw that his countenance was like the countenance of an angel.
So the high priest said, “Is this so?”

He began to speak and said, “Men, comrades, and patriarchs: listen to me. The God of Glory appeared to our ancestral patriarch Abraham while he was living in Mesopotamia, prior to him getting settled in Harran,
and told him, ‘Leave your homeland and your relatives and go to a country which I will point out to you at some point.’
He then left the country of Chaldea and settled in Harran. After his father died, from there he relocated to this country, to where we live now,

and he wasn’t given a tract of land in this country, one that he and his descendants would own in perpetuity—not even a tiny plot that would’ve been barely big enough to get by on—And he had been promised that, ‘This country be granted to him, given to him for him to own, he and his descendants—his progeny—after him,’ while not having a son at the time.

Here’s what God had to say to him: ‘This is what’s going to happen: his descendants—his progeny—will be foreigners and outsiders in another country, and those in the other country will enslave them and mistreat them for four hundred years.

And I will judge the nation (i.e. personally intervene and put an end to the evil that they’re doing) who made the decision to enslave you…,’ God said, ‘…and after these things have occurred, they will leave and come back to this place here and continuously offer up worship by attending to an ongoing service of rituals.’

”And He imparted to him a covenant comprised of circumcision. According to this set of instructions, he sired Isaac and circumcised him on the eighth day after his birth, and Isaac did this to Jacob, and Jacob to the twelve patriarchs, the ancestral founders of what would be the twelve tribes of Israel.
”But the patriarchs were jealous of Joseph and handed him over to be put in the custody of some Egyptians; but God was with him,

and delivered him out of all of his tribulations and gave him favor and wisdom in the presence of the king of Egypt, that is Pharaoh, and he was put in charge over Egypt and over his (Pharoah’s) entire ruling clan and staff.
Now a famine came out of nowhere and oppressed Egypt and Canaan causing a terrible ordeal, and our eleven patriarchal ancestors weren’t able to find enough food to eat.
Jacob heard that there was wheat in Egypt and sent out our ancestors as envoys to make the initial contact.
Second time around Joseph made himself known to his brothers, and Joseph’s birth, lineage, and ethnicity were made apparent to Pharaoh.
Joseph sent a message and summoned Jacob his father to his side and all the relatives, a total of seventy-five individuals,
and Jacob went down to Egypt. He died and so did our twelve ancestors,
they relocated to Shechem, and he was placed in the tomb which Abraham bought (paying in cash) from the sons of Hamor in Shechem.
”Just as the time for the fulfillment of the promise which God promised to Abraham got closer, the Israeli people grew and multiplied in Egypt,
until ‘…Another king ascended to power over Egypt, one who wasn’t affiliated with the Israeli people.’
This fellow used cunning, Machiavellian techniques against our people and mistreated our ancestors going so far as to expose their babies to the raw elements to where they wouldn’t survive.
That was the timeframe in which Moses was born, and he was polished, charming, courteous, polite, witty, and elegant to the highest degree—he who had spent three months being raised in momma’s house.
While he was exposed to the raw elements in order to die, Pharaoh’s daughter adopted him as her own son
and trained and disciplined Moses in every sort of Egyptian wisdom and sophistication; he was formidable in speech, ability, and actions.
”Now as he reached the age of forty, he felt an urging to visit his kinsmen, the Israelites.
While seeing someone being ill-treated, he came to his defense and took vengeance on the one being oppressed and struck down the Egyptian oppressor.
Now he was assuming that his brethren would understand that, through his abilities and actions, God was coming to their rescue, but they didn’t understand,
and the following day he appeared to some men as they were fighting and tried to get them to reconcile with one another and said, ‘Men, you’re kinsmen, why are you hurting each other?’
But one who was harming his acquaintance spurned him and said, ‘Who appointed you to be a ruler and a judge over us?
I hope you don’t want to eliminate me the same way you eliminated the Egyptian yesterday.’
Moses fled at this remark, and became a stranger and a foreigner in the land of Midian, where he gave birth to a couple of sons.
”When forty years were completed, ‘…An angel appeared to him in the Mt. Sinai wilderness in the flame of a burning bush.’
Seeing this, Moses was captivated by such a sight. While approaching it, a commanding voice appeared,
’I am the God of your forefathers, the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.’ Moses became terrified and dared not try to wrap his head around the whole thing.
’The Lord said to him, “Take your sandals off; the place on which you’ve come to stand is holy ground.
I’ve seen the mistreatment of My people in Egypt and have heeded their groaning and have come down to deliver them. Go now: I’m sending you to Egypt.”’
“This Moses whom they spurned by saying, ‘Who appointed you ruler and judge?’—this is the ruler and deliverer God sent with the assistance of an angel that was seen by him in the bush.
This person led them out of Egypt and performed spectacular miracles for forty years in the country of Egypt, in the Red Sea, and in the wilderness.
This person is Moses who said to the Israelites, ‘God will bring to prominence in your midst a prophet like me from among your kinsmen.’

”This is the fellow who was present in the gathering in the wilderness, along with the angel which spoke to him on Mt. Sinai and with our ancestors, and is the person who was shown living words to give to us,
whom our ancestors didn’t want to become subordinate to, but instead rejected and in their hearts turned back to Egypt,

having told Aaron, ‘Make us gods that will be our banner on the march and in battle, ensuring success at every turn. The fact is, this Moses-fellow who led us out of Egypt—we don’t know what’s become of him.’
During that timeframe they did the calf-making-thing and proceeded to offer up sacrifices to the idol and to rejoice in what their hands had wrought.

So God turned His head from them and let them have their own way in enacting worship to the vast array of planets and stars in the sky, just like it’s written in the prophet-section of the Old Testament,“‘You didn’t bring Me offerings and sacrificesWhen you were in the wilderness for forty years,Now did you house of Israel?

But you applied yourselves to Molok’s house of worship And to your star-god RephanAnd to the idols which you createdFor the purpose of worshipping them.Because of this I will exile youTo a place which is somewhere out beyond Babylon.’

the tabernacle which our ancestors took turns entering while Joshua was taking possession of the lands owned by foreign nations, nations which God drove out by the onslaughtof our ancestors up until the timeframe of David,
who found favor in the eyes of God, and he begged God that he would be allowed to come up with a plan to build a permanent tabernacle for the lineage of Jacob.
But instead Solomon built Him a building—a home—
but no—the Most High doesn’t reside in man-made structures, just like the prophet says,
“’To Me, the heavens are a throne And the earth is a stool that I use to rest My feet on.What sort of house will you make for me,’ says the Lord,‘Or what would be the place which I rest?
Has not My hand made all of these things?’
”Unyielding and unchanged in hearts and ears, you always resist the Holy Spirit; you’re just like your ancestors.

Tell me—which prophet did your ancestors not persecute? Which one? They killed those who announced ahead of time things associated with the coming of the Righteous Man, whom you’ve become traitors to and murderers of—
you the very people who received the Law of Moses, taking it to be an angelic ordinance, but didn’t keep it.”
Having heard these things, they were piqued and went into a rage of fury and proceeded to grit their teeth, biting down hard, gnashing them against him.

Being full of the Holy Spirit, he gazed up into the sky, to where heaven is, and saw God’s glorious magnificence and Jesus standing at God’s right hand (signifying that he’s completely vested in all executive powers)
and said, “Check this out—I see the sky up to heaven opened up and the Man standing at God’s right hand.”
They screamed with their ears covered tightly, rushed him in unison,

took him out of the city and proceeded to stone him to death. And the witnesses (who according to the Law of Moses must be the first to cast stones) took their jackets off and set them next to an aspiring young man named Saul.
As they were stoning Stephen he invokes heaven saying, “Lord Jesus, receive my spirit.”
He dropped to his knees and loudly shouted out, “Lord, may you not hold them accountable for this sin.” Having said this, he went to sleep (i.e. he died as a believer).

Now Saul whole-heartedly agreed with eliminating Stephen. On that day a terrible persecution broke out against the church—the gathering of believers—in Jerusalem. Everyone scattered over the Judean and Samarian countryside except for the apostles.
Devout men buried Stephen and mourned greatly for him during the period of mourning held for him.
Saul proceeded to go from house to house ravaging the church, barging in and dragging off men and women, arresting them and putting them in jail.
Those who were scattering throughout the countryside were announcing the good news message—proclaiming the Gospel, the good news of the Word.
Philip went over to a Samaritan city and proceeded to preach Christ to them.
The crowds eagerly took in the various statements made by Philip, united in one heart and mind in their listening and in their watching miracles that he performed.
The fact is, many filthy, disgusting spirits were being cast out one after another, crying out in a loud voice as they left. Many paralyzed and lame were being healed.
Much joy took place in that city.
Now a certain man named Simon used to awe the Samaritans in the city by practicing magic, claiming to be someone special,
a person who captivated everyone’s attention, from the insignificant to the important, what they were describing as, “God’s miracle-working power: the Bomb.”
They kept paying attention to him for a long time, dazzled by the works of magic.

But when they believed Philip proclaiming the good news of God’s kingdom and proclaiming the authority vested in Jesus Christ and what he’s all about, they proceeded to be baptized, men and women both.

Simon himself also believed and, once baptized, while sticking like glue to Philip and seeing spectacular miracles and tremendous miracle-working abilities, kept on becoming more and more enchanted by having been dazzled over and over again.
Now once the apostles in Jerusalem heard that Samaria had whole-heartedly embraced and acted upon God’s word, they sent them Peter and John,
such individuals who would go over and pray for them so that they would receive the Holy Spirit:
for he (the Holy Spirit) had not yet fallen upon any one of them, but they only existed in a state where they had been baptized into all that the Lord Jesus stands for.
Then they laid hands on them and they began receiving the Holy Spirit.
Simon, seeing the Spirit given through the apostles’ laying on of hands, offered them money
saying, “Give me this ability too, so that the person I lay my hands on would receive the Holy Spirit.”
But Peter said to him, “Get lost—I hope you die—you and your money along with you—since you assumed you could acquire God’s offering to mankind through cash.
You don’t get to participate in this business—not even a bit, seeing that your heart is not right in God’s sight.
So abandon this wickedness and beg the Lord if he would somehow possibly forgive your heart’s intention;
the fact is, I see that you’re coughing up bitterness and are handcuffed by unrighteousness.”
In response, Simon said, “You all pray to the Lord on my behalf, so that I won’t be afflicted by what you’ve said.”
So then they thoroughly presented and spoke about the concept of the Lord and returned to Jerusalem, and many Samaritan towns began to have the good news proclaimed in them.
Now an angel spoke to Philip, “Head on out south on the road which runs from Jerusalem to Gaza, the one that nobody uses.”
He got going. Out of nowhere an Ethiopian man appeared, a eunuch who had control over the Queen of Ethiopia’s entire treasury, one who had gone to Jerusalem to worship
and was on the return trip sitting on his chariot and reading out of the prophet Isaiah.
The Spirit said to Philip, “Go up to him and join his chariot.”
Philip ran over to him and heard him reading out of the prophet Isaiah, and said, “Hmm…do you really understand what you’re reading?”
He said, “Ya, about that. How would I be able to unless someone walks me through it?”, and he asked Philip to climb aboard the chariot, sit down together with him, and help him out.
The passage of Scripture which he was in the middle of reading was this: Like a sheep led to slaughterAnd like a lamb speechless before the shearer:In the same way he won’t open his mouth.
In his self-abasement his justice has been stripped from him. How can anyone possibly describeThe prevailing Zeitgeist of his time,Since his life has been wiped off the face of the Earth?
Upon reflection the eunuch said to Philip, “Can I ask you whom the prophet’s talking about here? Is he talking about himself or about someone else?”
Philip opened his mouth and, from this passage of Scripture, began to tell him all about the good news of Jesus.
As they were going down the road, they stumbled across some water, and the eunuch said, “Look—water: what’s stopping me from getting baptized?”
He ordered his chariot to come to a halt, and both of them—Philip and the eunuch—got off the chariot and went into the water, and Philip baptized him.
When they got out of the water, the Spirit of the Lord took hold of Philip and redirected him, and the eunuch didn’t see him anymore; you see, he was going his way rejoicing.
Philip wound up in Azotus, and while travelling through there kept on proclaiming the good news to all of the cities all the way to Caesarea.
Saul, still huffing murderous threats at the Lord’s disciples, went to the high priest

and asked—begged—for letters of authorization from him to present to the synagogues in Damascus, so that if he were to find anyone belonging to “the Way”, either man or woman, once they’re caught and tied with rope, he would lead them to Jerusalem.
While travelling he was nearing Damascus and suddenly a light from up in the sky—from out of heaven—flashed around him,
and he fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to him,
He said, “Who are you, sir?”
His fellow travellers stood speechless, without doubt hearing the voice but not seeing anyone.
Saul got up off the ground, and when his eyes were opened, he couldn’t see a thing; he entered Damascus being led by the hand.
For three days he had no sight and didn’t eat or drink anything.

Now there was a certain disciple in Damascus named Ananias. The Lord spoke to him in a dream,
He said, “I’m here, Lord.”
The Lord told him,
Ananias replied, “Lord, a lot of people have told me about this man, about how much harm he’s done to the set-apart-people in Jerusalem—
and he has the backing of the high priest to catch and tie up anyone in this location who’s inviting you into his life.”
The Lord said to him,

So Ananias left and entered the house, laid his hands upon him, and said, “Saul, fellow comrade, the Lord sent me—Jesus, the one who appeared to you while you were on the way here—in order that you would regain your sight would be filled with the Holy Spirit.”
And without delay something akin to fish scales fell away from his eyes, and he regained his sight. He took the initiative and was baptized.
Once he got something to eat, he was invigorated. He spent several days with the Damascus disciples.
He straightaway proceeded to preach Jesus—that this person is the Son of God—in the synagogues.

Again and again everyone who heard him was amazed, and they started saying, “Isn’t this the guy who’s wreaking havoc on those in Jerusalem who’ve invited Jesus into their lives? Hasn’t he come here for the same reason, so that he could take the ones he’s caught, tie them up, and bring them right to the high priest?”
But Saul proceeded to become all the more forceful and confounded the Jews living in Damascus, demonstrating through proofs that this very person Jesus is the Messiah, the Christ.
As a good many days had gone by and things were coming to a head, the Jews conspired to eliminate him,
but their plot became known to Saul. They even started monitoring the gates closely, not just by day but by night too, so that they could eliminate him,
but in spite of this disciples took him one night and put him all the way through the city wall and lowered him down in a large basket.
After arriving in Jerusalem, he kept attempting to join up with the disciples, but a lot of them kept on being afraid of him, not believing that he actually was a disciple.

So Barnabas got ahold of him and brought him to the apostles and told them all about him: how he was on the road and saw the Lord, and that the Lord spoke to him…how in Damascus he was speaking out on behalf of Jesus and all that he stands for.
and he proceeded to speak to and to have discussions—to the point of arguing—with the Greek-speaking Jews, but they tried to apprehend him in order to eliminate him.
The comrades recognized that this was a problem and brought him over to Caesarea and sent him away to Tarsus.

So now the church up and down the entire stretch of Judea, Galilee, and Samaria experienced peace, being edified and conducting their lives in the deep reverence—the fear—of the Lord, and with the assistance and comfort of the Holy Spirit, they were growing and growing.
While Peter happened to be travelling all throughout the area, he also went over to the-set-apart-ones living in Lydda.
He found a man there, a certain person named Aeneas, who had been bedfast for the last eight years, a person who had become paralyzed.
Peter told him, “Aeneas, Jesus Christ is healing you: get up and make your bed.” Immediately he got up.
Everyone living in Lydda and Sharon saw him; those very people turned to the Lord.
Now in Joppa there was a certain disciple named Tabitha, which translated means “Dorcas.” She was teeming in good works and in donations to the poor, which she was constantly contributing.
During that timeframe she happened to get run-down with an illness, becoming sick to the point of death and eventually dying. They bathed her and put her in the top floor of a building.
Lydda being close to Joppa, the disciples heard that Peter was over there and sent two men to him asking him earnestly—begging him, “Hurry up! Come over to our place!”

Peter got up and went with them and, once he arrived, was ushered up to the upper floor. All the widows stood next to him crying and showing the oh-so-many tunics and cloaks which she was in the habit of making while she was with them.
Peter pushed everyone out of the room, and got on his knees and prayed and turned to the body and said, “Tabitha, get up!” She opened her eyes and, seeing Peter, sat up.
He gave her a hand and got her up. He called for the set-apart-people and presented her alive from the dead.
What happened became known up and down the entire Joppa stretch, and many believed in the Lord.
As it turned out, he remained a good amount of time in Joppa with one Simon Tanner.
In Caesarea a certain man named Cornelius, a centurion in a battalion named “From (the Roman province of) Italia,”
a devout Gentile who, together with his entire household, was a sympathizer and near-convert to Judaism, often giving contributions to the poor-folk and constantly praying to God,
around three o’clock in the afternoon distinctly saw an angel in a vision enter this world and go to him and say, “Cornelius.”

Once he stared at him, he became afraid and said, “What is it, sir?” He told him, “Your prayers and donations have percolated upwards to where they’ve garnered God’s attention, and He’s quite pleased by what He sees.
Send a few men to Joppa right now and summon Simon, who goes by ‘Peter.’
This fellow’s being boarded by one Simon Tanner, whose house is next to the sea.”
As the angel who was speaking to him left, he called for two men from his household staff and a pious soldier from among those who waited on him.
He explained everything to them and dispatched them to Joppa.
During the next day, while those men were on the road and getting near to the city, Peter went out on the back deck around noon to pray.
He got hungry and had a hankering to eat. While they were getting the noon meal ready, what happened is that he fell into a trance
and sees that the sky had been opened up and sees an object something like a huge, four-cornered cloth sheet coming down, being lowered to the ground,

on top of which was every type of four-footed animal, were reptiles, and were birds from the sky—In other words, all sorts of animals which, according to Jewish kosher laws, Jews are forbidden to eat.
Out of nowhere a voice addressed him, “Get to it, Peter: slaughter and eat them.”
But Peter said, “No way, sir, since I’ve never eaten anything which isn’t kosher.”
Again a second time a voice from the sky spoke to him, “The item which God has purged of its non-kosher-ness is permissible for you to eat.”
This happened a third time and immediately after that the object was taken up into the sky.

While Peter was turning things over in his head, being stumped at what the vision he’d witnessed could possibly mean, out of nowhere the men who were sent by Cornelius stopped at the gate asking around about Simon’s house,
and in their conversation proceeded to inquire if Simon who goes by Peter was staying at this place.
While Peter was thinking over the vision, the Spirit told him, “Take a look—three men are looking for you.
Enough said—go down, go over, and introduce yourself to them; I’ve sent them, no doubt.”
So Peter went over to the men and said, “Hey, I’m the one you’re looking for. What’s the reason you’ve come?”

They said, “Cornelius, a centurion, a righteous man and a Jewish-sympathizer—plus well-spoken-of and respected by the whole Jewish race—was divinely instructed by an angel to have you sent to his house and to listen to a message by you.”
As a result he invited them in and entertained them, letting them stay at his place. The next day, he got ready and departed with them, and some of the comrades from Joppa came with him.
The following day, they arrived in Caesarea; Cornelius was waiting for them to arrive and gathered together his close friends and relatives.
Now just as Peter arrived, Cornelius went up to him and prostrated himself before him in worship.
Peter got him up by saying, “Get up: me—I’m just a human being.”
Conversing with him, he entered the house and discovered that a lot of people had gathered there

and said to them, “You understand that it’s forbidden for a Jewish man to associate with or visit someone of another race. But God showed me that the item which has been purged of its non-kosher-ness (talking about a person in this case) is to be permitted.
Therefore, I had no objection to coming when you sent for me. So let me ask: what reason have you summoned me?”

Cornelius said, “Starting four days ago up until this very moment we were praying just like we pray during the Three-in-the-Afternoon-Prayer-Time in my house, and—just like that—a man dressed in white appeared out of nowhere and stood in front of me
and said, ‘Cornelius, your prayers and donations have percolated upwards to where they’ve garnered God’s attention, and He’s quite pleased by what He sees.
So now, send some men to Joppa and send for Simon who goes by Peter. This fellow’s being boarded in Simon Tanner’s house next to the sea.’

So without delay I dispatched some men your way, and you’ve kindly acquiesced to being brought here. So at this time all of us are on the edge of our seats waiting to hear and to obey everything that you’ve been directed and commanded by the Lord.”
Peter opened his mouth and said, “I’m really, really floored by the fact that God doesn’t show partiality,
but instead those in every race, culture, and nationality who reverence Him and go about doing right are acceptable to Him.
He sent the word out to the Israeli descendants issuing a good-news proclamation of peace through Jesus Christ—this person is everyone’s Lord—
you know about it: the affair that happened all throughout Judea, starting in Galilee after the baptism that John preached:

That God singled out and specially chose Jesus of Nazareth and put on him an oh-so-powerful-dose of the miracle-working power of the Holy Spirit, who then, since God was with him, went throughout the confines of Israel doing good works and healing all who were being oppressed by the devil.
We ourselves are eyewitnesses to all that he did in the country occupied by the Jews and in Jerusalem—he that they hung on a wooden cross-beam and killed.
God resurrected this fellow on the third day and caused him to be seen by the naked eye and appear before people,

but not to be seen by any-old person but instead to provide evidence to those hand-picked beforehand by God—that is us—the very people who ate and drank together with him after his resurrection from the dead.
He commanded us to preach to the folk-people and to solemnly testify that this fellow is the one who’s been promised by God; this fellow is a judge of the living and the dead.
To this end, all of the prophets affirm the receiving of forgiveness of sins through his authority and what he stands for…”

While Peter was still in the middle of saying this, the Holy Spirit fell (i.e. they were baptized in the Holy Spirit by the Spirit manifesting Himself in a strong, sudden way inside of them, to the point of having trouble keeping control of themselves) on everyone who was listening to the message.

The believers who were dedicated to a strict form of Judaism who accompanied Peter were flabbergasted because the offering—the gift—of the baptism in the Holy Spirit was poured out on the Gentiles, those who are not Jewish by birth or by conversion:
for they heard them speaking in tongues and magnifying God. Then Peter reacted to what had happened,
“Surely water for someone to be baptized in can’t be denied to these people, particularly those who received the Holy Spirit just like we did?”
He commanded that they be baptized by the authority of of Jesus Christ. After that, they asked him to stay for several days.
Now the apostles and comrades over in Judea heard that the Gentiles too and not just the Jews had whole-heartedly embraced and acted upon God's word, God’s system of logic.
When Peter went over to Jerusalem, the believers who adhered to Judaism strictly proceeded to show that they had misgivings about what he did and questioned what he did:
“You went into a house that has those outside of Judaism in it and shared a meal with them.”
Peter proceeded to explain to them what happened, explaining it in sequential order:

“I was in Joppa praying and had a vision while in a trance: the vision was of an object something like a huge, four-cornered cloth sheet descending out of the sky, and it came as far as me and stopped.
I stared at it and started to notice what was there: I saw the gamut of four-footed animals, wild beasts, reptiles, and birds from the sky.
Along with it, I heard a voice telling me, ‘Get to it, Peter: slaughter and eat them.’
But I said, ‘No way, sir, since nothing which isn’t kosher has ever entered my mouth.’
A second time a voice from the sky spoke in reply, ‘That which God has purged of its non-kosher-ness is permissible for you to eat.’
This happened a third time, and the objects in the vision were taken back up into the sky again.
Just like that, three men stopped at the house which I was staying, men sent as messengers from Cornelius to me.
The Spirit told me to have no doubts or reservations and go introduce myself to them. Some of the comrades—these fellows here—also accompanied me, and we entered the man’s house.
”He reported how he saw an angel in his house, and the angel stood there and said, ‘Send messengers to Joppa and send for Simon who goes by Peter,
who’ll speak to you and tell you things by which you will be rescued from your spiritual malaise, you and your entire household.’
While I was just getting started talking, the baptism in the Holy Spirit fell on them just like it did on us too way-back-when.
But I remembered the Lord’s sayings, as he kept on telling us,
So now, if God gave the same exact offering—gift—to them as He gave to us too, to believe in the Lord Jesus Christ, who was I to stand in God’s way?”
After hearing this, they fell silent and glorified God saying, “Then that means that God also granted the Gentiles the Complete-Changeover which leads to that special fullness of life.”

So now, those who were scattered because of the pressure due to the persecution that occurred upon Stephen’s stoning spread out as far as Phoenicia, Cyprus, and Antioch telling the Concept to Jews alone.

Among them were some men from Cyprus and Cyrene, men in particular who went to Antioch and were talking and talking to the Greek-speaking Jews, telling them the good news—the Gospel—of the Lord Jesus.
The Lord was supernaturally and spectacularly working behind the scenes in conjunction with them, and consequently there were many people who believed and turned to the Lord.
The whole story was heard by the ears of the church in Jerusalem, and they dispatched Barnabas, who passed through the region until he got to Antioch.

Once he got there and got to see the manifestation of God’s grace, rejoiced. Because he was a good man, full of the Holy Spirit, and faithful, he advised, encouraged, and in every way helped them all with a heartfelt determination to stick with it until the Lord comes back.
—And a good-many people were added to the Lord.
He left for Tarsus to hunt Saul down,

and once he found him brought him to Antioch. As things turned out in their case, they got together in the church for a whole year and taught a good number of people, and as a result the disciples were first referred to as “Christians” in Antioch.
During this timeframe, prophets went from Jerusalem to Antioch.

One of them by the name of Agabus stood up and through the Spirit portended that a huge famine over the entire civilized worldwas going to occur, which happened during the Roman Emperor Claudius’s reign.
The disciples reacted in such a way that what came out of them was that each one of them, as far as he had the means to do so, determined to send a ministry-gift to the comrades living in Judea.
They did just that and sent the money they collected to the presiding board, the leaders of the church in Jerusalem, using Barnabas and Saul as couriers.
About that time, King Herod seized a few people who belonged to the church in order to mistreat them badly.
He killed John’s brother James with a sword.
Seeing how pleasing this was to the Judeans, he proceeded to take it a step further and apprehend Peter too (it was around Passover),

whom he arrested and put in jail, putting him in the custody of four squads (a squad consisting of four men) of soldiers who would guard him, intending to haul him up before the folk-people after the Passover.
So now, Peter was being kept in jail; the church continued praying fervently to God for him.
When Herod was about to lead him forth to his death, Peter was sleeping that night between two soldiers, chained up with two chains. In addition to that, two soldiers were guarding the door.
Out of nowhere, an angel went up to him and a light shined in the cell. He tapped Peter’s chest and woke him up saying,“Get up—quickly now!”His chains fell from his arms.
The angel told him, “Put your shirt and pants on and put your sandals on.” He did just that. He then says to him, “Put your jacket on and follow me.”
Once he left the prison, he followed him, but because of the angel he didn’t know that what was happening was for real; he kept on thinking that he was having a dream.

After passing through the night watchmen’s first checkpoint and through the second, they went to the Iron Gate, the gate people use when carrying things into the city. That very gate opened automatically itself for them, and after they left the city, they went down one narrow street and immediately the angel left him.
Peter came to his senses and said, “Now I know for certain that the Lord sent one of his angels and delivered me from Herod’s clutches and from all that awaited me from the Judean folk-people.”
Realising where he was, he went to Mary’s house (Mary the mother of John, who goes by “Mark”), where a good number of people were gathered praying.
He knocked on the outer courtyard door and a girl named Rhoda went to answer it.
Recognizing Peter’s voice, out of joy she didn’t open the door but ran in and announced that Peter’s standing at the door.
They told her, “You’re crazy,” but she kept on insisting that it’s so. They kept on telling her, “It’s his messenger,”
but Peter stayed there knocking, so they opened the door, saw him, and just lost it.

He motioned with his hand to get them to quiet down and began to explain how the Lord led him out of the prison; in addition, he told them, “Go out and tell these things to James and his brothers.” He left and went to some other place.
When daylight came, no small amount of commotion took place among the soldiers: what exactly happened to Peter?
Herod looked for him and upon not finding him interrogated the guards and ordered that they be taken away and executed and left Judea for Caesarea and proceeded to spend time there.

Now he was furious with Tyre and Sidon; but in the solidarity of a unified front, they approached him and, once they won the king’s chamberlain Blastus over to their side, kept begging for peace on account of their country being fed out of the king’s grain silos.
On a prearranged date, Herod, fully clothed in his regal apparel and presiding in his official capacity as judge, proceeded to address them.
The populace kept shouting out, “We’re hearing a god’s voice and not a human voice!”
Immediately an angel struck him in retaliation for not coming clean and telling the truthby letting that remark slide, and he wound up being eaten by worms and breathed his last.
The Word of God kept on growing and multiplying.
Having fulfilled their mission, Barnabas and Saul returned from Jerusalem and took along with them John who goes by Mark.

Now there were prophets and teachers interspersed throughout the church in Antioch: Barnabas, Simeon who goes by Niger, and Lucius the Cyrenian; Manaen a close, boyhood friend (might’ve even been a foster brother) of the tetrarch Herod, and Saul.
While worshipping the Lord in worship services and while fasting, the Holy Spirit told them, “Consecrate Barnabas and Saul to the work that I have called them.”
Then, after fasting, praying, and laying hands on them, they turned them loose.
So then they, having been dispatched by the Holy Spirit, went over to Seleucia, and from there sailed out to Cyprus.
When they wound up in Salamis, they proclaimed God’s word in the Jews’ synagogues. Now he had Mark around to run errands for him and to help with odds-and-ends.
After they went through the entire island all the way to Paphos, they ran across a particular man, a sorcerer/false-prophet Jew who adopted the name “Joshua-2.0,”
an associate of the intelligent, quick-witted Roman proconsul Sergius Paulus. This fellow Sergius Paulus summoned Barnabas and Saul, seeking to hear all about God’s word.
The sorcerer Elymas (that’s the way his name—Joshua-2.0’s name, that is—is translated), though, opposed them, trying to distort the message, steering the proconsul away from the faith.
But Saul (which is also “Paul”), being full of the Holy Spirit, glared at him

and said, “Oh, aren’t you full of all kinds of deception, trickery, and unscrupulousness, you spitting image of the devil, you enemy of any shape or form of righteousness?—You won’t pause for a moment in your turning people away by your distortion of the Lord’s Straightforward Ways.

See here: a supernatural working of the Lord’s power will assail you right this moment, and you’ll become blind—not even able to see the sun—for a duration of time”—and immediately a total loss of sight to where everything went completely dark was imposed upon him, and he began to go around trying to find a blind-man’s guide to lead him about by the hand.
Upon seeing what had happened, the proconsul then believed, astonished at the lesson that the Lord taught Elymas.
Paul and the band which surrounded him put out to sea at Paphos and went to Perga, Pamphylia. Mark, however, left them and returned to Jerusalem.
For their part, though, starting at Perga, they cut across and arrived in Antioch-Pasidia, and attended a synagogue meeting on the Sabbath, introduced themselves, and took a seat.
After the bringing-out of the Old Testament scrolls, the synagogue heads sent them a message, “Men, comrades, if any one of you has an encouraging word for the folk-people, speak up.”
Paul stood up, gestured with his hand, and said: “Men, Israelites, and Gentile sympathizers to Judaism, listen to what I have to say.
The God of this people Israel chose our ancestors and brought them to prominence in the temporary stay in Egypt, and by a supernatural intervention in the affairs of mankind brought them out of there
and tolerated them for about forty years in the wilderness.
After destroying seven nations in Canaan, he took possession of their land,
occupying it for about 450 years. After this, He designated ad-hoc rulers until the prophet Samuel came on the scene.
And then they asked for a king, and God gave them Saul son of Kish, a man from the clan of Benjamin, for forty years.

Once he was removed, He brought David to prominence, making him their king. He went on record and said about him, ‘I found David son of Jesse, a man after My heart, one who does everything I ever wanted.’
From out of this fellow’s lineal descendants God brought Israel to a savior named Jesus, according to what had been promised,
John having preached ahead of time, before Jesus came on the scene, a baptism, an initiation ceremony of a change of heart and of ways, to all the people of Israel.

But as John crossed the finish line and his ministry was waning, he kept on saying, ‘What do you all suppose that I am? I am not the One—No—get ahold of this: he who comes after me—I am not worthy to take his sandal off.’

”Men, comrades, descendants of Abraham’s line, and those Gentiles among you who are Jewish sympathizers: the message of this rescue-plan rescuing you from your spiritual malaise has been sent out to you.
The fact is, those who live in Jerusalem along with their rulers, not acknowledging this and the voices of the prophets which are read aloud every Sabbath, finished coming to a verdict,
and—without a single one of them finding a reason for the death penalty—asked Pilate to kill Jesus.
Just as all the things noted about him in the Scriptures were fulfilled, they took him down off the wooden cross-beam and put him in a tomb—
But God resurrected him from the dead,
the one who for many days was seen by those who accompanied him from Galilee to Jerusalem, by the very people who are declaring to the folk-people that this is indeed factual.
And we are delivering the good news to you all, that what was promised to the forefathers has occurred,
because God has fulfilled this among us the descendants, having resurrected Jesus, as there is also a verse in the second Psalms which reads:“You are My son:I have begotten you today

”Since He resurrected him from the dead, he’s not going to be returning to bodily decomposition ever again. This has resulted in the following being the case:“I will give you David’s holy things, his guaranteed things
”Consequently, there’s another place where it says: “You will not destine Your Holy-OneTo undergo bodily decomposition
”Indeed, when his own generation was alive, David attended to the will of God and expired and went to be with his ancestors and underwent decomposition,
but the one whom God raised from the dead didn’t undergo decomposition.

So now, let it be known, men, comrades, that through this resurrection forgiveness of sins is being proclaimed to you—forgiveness of everything which you have not been justified in doing by the Law of Moses.
By this resurrection, everyone who believes is justified.
So see to it that what’s been spoken by the Old Testament prophets not get the better of you:

”Here they are, the cynics and the scoffers: Gape at them for a moment and then vanish,Because I’m doing something special in your lifetime.There’s no way at all that you would believe what I’m up to,Even if someone were to describe it to you.”
While they were saying goodbye, they kept pleading with him to speak to them on the following Sabbath, to talk some more about what was said.

Once they were dismissed from the synagogue service, many of the Jews and the devout proselytes to Judaism followed Paul and Barnabas. While certain ones of them in particular were speaking face-to-face with them, Paul and Barnabas kept on persuading them to continue in the grace of God.
On the following Sabbath, almost the entire city gathered together to hear the Word of the Lord.
Seeing how many were in the crowd, the Jews were filled with envy and proceeded to say things in opposition to what was spoken by Paul, contradicting him and blaspheming him,

and so Paul and Barnabas, speaking to the wider audience, said, “It was necessary to speak the Word of God to you first, but since you reject it and render yourselves unworthy of that special fullness of life (eternal life), take note: I’m turning to the Gentiles.

You see, the Lord has given you commands to follow like this: “I have positioned you JewsTo be a light for Gentile nations,In order that you be a means of rescue and refugeTo the furthest reaches of the planet.”
Hearing this, the Gentiles proceeded to rejoice and to glorify the Word of the Lord, and the very ones who were appointed to eternal life believed.
Now the Word of the Lord kept on being spread throughout the whole country.
The Jews incited the pious women, the ones who were prominent and who were leaders in the city, fomented a persecution against Paul and Barnabas, and kicked them out of their district.
They wiped their hands of it and went to Iconium,
and the disciples kept on being filled with a Holy-Spirit-fueled-joy.

In Iconium events occurred along the same lines: they introduced themselves to the members of the synagogue and affiliated themselves with it in order to speak before the synagogue so that a great many Jews, and not only they but Greek-speaking Jews, would become believers.
The Jews who weren’t converted to the faith went on the offensive against them and polluted the minds of the Gentiles, pitting them against the comrades.
So then they stayed a good deal of time speaking openly about the Lord, testifying about the message of his grace, allowing miracles to take place through their hands.
The majority of the population was divided: on the one hand there were those of the Jews’ camp; on the other hand there were those of the apostles’ camp.
Spontaneously and impulsively, both the Gentiles and the Jews were joined by their rulers and decided to attack them and stone them.
Realizing what was going on, they got out of there and fled to the cities of Lycaonian, Lystra and Derbe specifically and to the surrounding area.
There they continually shared the good news, the good news of the Gospel.
There was a certain helpless man in Lystra—unable to use his legs—who kept on sitting on the ground all the time, lame from the time he was born, one who hadn’t walked around even once.
This fellow heard Paul speaking; after Paul stared at him, and while staring sees that he has the faith to escape his affliction,
he said in a loud voice, “Get up on your feet and stand straight up!”—and he proceeded to do just that: he sprung up and walked around,
and seeing what Paul did the crowd raised their voices in the Lycaonian language saying, “The gods came down to us in the form of these men!”—
and they proceeded to call Barnabas “Zeus” and Paul “Hermes,” since Paul did most of the talking—

and the priest of Zeus, whose temple is situated right before you get to the city, brought bulls and the garlands that sacrificial animals are adorned with to the city gates and, joined by the crowds, was itching to perform sacrifices.
When the apostles Barnabas and Paul heard this, they tore their garments to show how upset they were and rushed out into the crowd yelling,

“Men, why are you doing this? We too are men who experience passion and pain the same way you do, while at the same time telling you the good news of turning away from these worthless things to a living God, who made the sky, the earth, the sea, and everything along with them,
who in the bygone generations permitted people everywhere to go their own way and do their own thing—

and yet He didn’t leave them void of evidence pointing to Him being up in heaven doing good things and being kind, giving you that sweet rain which makes for productive growing seasons, the food injecting gladness into your hearts until your hearts are filled to the brim.”
Saying these things just barely caused the crowd to stop performing sacrifices.
Now Jews from Antioch and Iconium arrived, talked the crowd into stoning Paul, did just that, and dragged him and dragged him until they got outside the city, thinking he was dead.
While his disciples were standing around him in a circle, he got up and went back into the city. The next day he left for Derbe accompanied by Barnabas,
and after he proclaimed the good news of the Gospel to that city and made a decent number of disciples there, returned to Lystra, then to Iconium, and then to Antioch,

getting the life-being of the disciples to rely on the Lord, encouraging them to stick with the faith and advising them by saying that a lot of difficulties and intense pressure will occur and must be endured in order to succeed in their life of faith (enter God’s kingdom).
Now having prayed, combining fasting with the prayer, he went church by church and appointed presiding boards, and the Lord kept on adding more people to those who had already come to believe.
They passed through Pisidia and came to Pamphylia,
and after speaking the Word of God in Perga, they went down to Attalia.
From there they sailed to Antioch, from where they started the trip, and were commended for the mission they accomplished by the grace of God.

After getting there and gathering the church together, they proceeded to report what God did, as He was with them on the trip, and to report that He opened a door of faith for the Gentiles (i.e. He created an opportunity for the Gentiles to join the faith).
They continued to spend time—and no small amount of it—with the disciples.

A few key people came over from Judea and proceeded to tell them how things ought to be done, instructing the comrades that you’ve got to be circumcised in Moses (i.e. become Jewish and commit to obeying the commandments in the Law of Moses), or else you can’t be saved (i.e. receive Christ and walk with him).

No small disagreement and debate occurred between Paul and Barnabas on one side and them on the other, and they arranged for Paul, Barnabas, and certain others from among them to go to the apostles and the presiding board in Jerusalem in regard to this debate.
So then those sent forth by the church kept creating tremendous joy among the comrades as they were passing through Phoenicia and Samaria recounting the Gentiles’ conversion.
Arriving in Jerusalem, they were welcomed by the church, the apostles, and the presiding board, and reported what God was doing in conjunction with them.

Now a few who belonged to the Pharisee-sect and who had become believers stood up to speak and said that the Gentile believers must be circumcised (and thus convert to Judaism) and be ordered to adhere to the Law of Moses,
and the apostles and the presiding board got together to look into this matter.

After much debate took place, Peter stood up and told them: “Men, comrades: you understand that from the very start (our start that is), God chose that the Gentiles hear the Gospel through my mouth and become believers.
God, the Knower-Of-The-Heart, went on record and told them that He would give them the baptism of the Holy Spirit just like He gave it to us.
After their hearts were cleansed by faith, no one discriminated against them.

So at this point in time, you’re trying God’s patience (testing God) by placing an unnecessary burden on the disciples (putting a yoke on the disciples’ necks), one which neither our ancestors nor we were strong enough to bear.
No—it’s through the grace of the Lord Jesus that one exercises faith to be saved from their sin following the same pattern as those people did.”
The whole lot of them fell silent and began to listen to Barnabas and Paul explain the miracles that God did among the Gentiles through them.
After their silence, James responded, “Men, comrades, listen to me.

Simon explained the way that, for the first time, God paid a visit—a caring, helping type of visit—in order to form a unique group of people from out of the Gentiles, a people consecrated to everything He represents.
The words of the prophets agree with this, as it’s written:
”’After this occurs, I will return And rebuild David’s fallen condoAnd rebuild what remains of itAnd restore it,
So that what’s left of the people Just might seek out the Lord,Plus all of the Gentiles upon whomMy mark of ownership was assigned to,’Says the Lord who’s doing this
and Who’s been making this known from eternity past.
”Therefore I decided not to bother those who are of Gentile origin who are turning to God,

but instead to write them letters which tell them to abstain from the detestable things forbidden by of the Law of Moses: from things polluted by idols, from bizarre sexual immorality, and from drinking the blood remaining in the body of an animal after it’s been killed by having its neck broken.
You see, going back to ancient times, the Law of Moses has always had those who preach it, as it’s being read aloud in the synagogues in city after city, Sabbath after Sabbath.”

Then the apostles and the presiding board in conjunction with the entire church decided what was best to do and chose men from among them to send with Paul and Barnabas to Antioch, namely Judas, who goes by Barsabbas, and Silas, men who were leaders among their comrades,

and wrote a certified letter so there would be no doubt of its authenticity, “The apostles and the presiding board, comrades: to the comrades up and down Antioch, Syria, and Cilicia, those who are of Gentile origin. Greetings!
Because we heard that some of our own people have of their own initiative ventured out and troubled you with remarks unsettling to your mind, people who have not been issued instructions to do so,
all of us were in agreement in deciding what was best to do and chose comrades to send you who will accompany our beloved Barnabas and Paul,
men who have dedicated their lives to to all that our Lord Jesus Christ stands for.
So we have sent Judas and Silas, and they will report the same as what is written here through word-of-mouth.
The fact is, the Holy Spirit and we thought it best not to make you shoulder any more burden than these items which we’re listing here, which are absolutely necessary:
abstain from food sacrificed to idols, from slaughtering an animal with the intent of drinking its blood, and from bizarre sexual immorality.”
So then, once they were released, they went up to Antioch, gathered the community of believers together, and gave them the letter.
After it was read they rejoiced at the advice, exhortation, and encouragement.
Judas and Silas as well exhorted and encouraged the comrades by means of many short prophetic messages (they being prophets in their own right) and put them on a firm footing.
After putting in time there, they were released in good standing from the comrades back to the ones who sent them.
Paul and Barnabas continued on in Antioch teaching and evangelizing the Word of the Lord, and many others did too.

After some days Paul said to Barnabas, “Let’s return to the cities in which we proclaimed the word of the Lord and go from city to city visiting the comrades there and see how they’re getting on in their faith.”
Now Barnabas was wanting to take Mark (i.e. John who goes by Mark) along with them too,
but Paul was thinking it fitting not to take Mark along, the guy who deserted them, leaving them at Pamphylia and ceasing to accompany them on their mission.
A sharp disagreement took place to the point where they parted ways from each other, and Barnabas took Mark and sailed for Cyprus.
Paul called on Silas to accompany him and left, after being handed over to the Lord’s grace for safe keeping by the comrades.
He went on and on passing through Syria putting the churches on a firm footing.

Paul arrived in Derbe and then in Lystra and stumbled across a particular disciple there named Timothy, the son of a Jewish woman who was a believer in Christ but whose father was a Greek-speaking westerner,
whose good reputation was attested to by the comrades in Lystra and Iconium.

Paul wanted this fellow to leave with him, and took him to get circumcised (symbolizing his conversion to Judaism and the beginning of his obeying the Law of Moses) because of the Jews that were in that locale. You see, they all knew that he had a father who was a westerner.
As they were travelling through the cities, they committed themselves to keeping an eye on the issues that had been decided by the apostles and the presiding board in Jerusalem.
So then the churches were being strengthened in the faith and were increasing in number day by day.

After passing through Phrygia and the province of Galatia, they were prevented from speaking the Word by the Holy Spirit in the Roman province of Asia, in which Phrygia is located and which borders Galatia.
After they went over to Mysia, they kept on trying to go to Bithynia, but the Spirit of Jesus didn’t allow them to.
After making an appearance in Mysia, they went over to Troas.
A vision was seen by Paul over the course of a night: some Macedonian man stood planted in one place begging him, “Cut across the Aegean Sea to Macedonia and help us out.”
Like he saw in the vision, we immediately sought to depart for Macedonia surmising that God had summoned us there to evangelize them.
They sailed from Troas straight to Samothrace, and the next day to Neapolis,
and from there to Philippi, which is a leading colony-city in that part of Macedonia. We were keeping at it in this city for a number of days,
and on the Sabbath we went out the city gates and down by the river, figuring it would be a good place to pray. We sat down and proceeded to speak to the women who had formed a group there.

A particular woman named Lydia, a dealer in luxurious cloth, a Thyatirian sympathizer and near-convert to Judaism, was listening and listening, as the Lord opened her heart to heed what was being spoken by Paul.

As she was baptized (and her household was too), she asked earnestly, “If you’ve come to the conclusion that I’m faithful to the Lord, come stay at my house,” and she wouldn’t take “no” for an answer.

Now it so happened as they were going to a prayer meeting, that some teenage servant-girl who had a spirit of divination accosted them, one who brought her bosses a hefty sum of money by telling fortunes.
She followed Paul around and kept on yelling, “These men are servants of the Most High God, ones who are proclaiming what you need to do to set things right with God,” about them,
and she kept this up for several days. Paul, exasperated, turned to the spirit and said, “By the authority vested in me by Jesus Christ, I command you to leave her!”—and it left her that moment.
Seeing that any hope of generating income departed when the spirit departed, her bosses seized Paul and Silas and dragged them to the main town square to where the rulers were.
They brought them to the magistrates and said, “These here men are agitating our city, seeing that they’re Jews.
They proclaim—impose upon us—sets of rules which are impermissible for us to embrace, seeing that we’re Romans.”
The crowd joined in on attacking them. The magistrates flew off the handle and ordered them to be beaten with rods,
and after wounding them with many blows threw them in jail and ordered the jail keeper to lock them up tightly,
who, once he received such a stern order, shuttled them deep inside the jail and put their legs in stocks.
Towards the middle of the night while Paul and Silas were praying, they kept on singing praises to God (and the prisoners kept hearing from them).

A severe earthquake took place suddenly, one of such a magnitude that it shook the foundation of the jailhouse, and immediately all the doors were opened, and all of the stocks, chains, and fetters were unfastened.
The jail keeper was awakened, and seeing all the jail’s doors opened, drew his sword and was about to kill himself, thinking that all the prisoners had escaped,
but Paul called out to him in a loud voice, “Don’t hurt yourself; we’re all still here, you see.”
He called for a torch, ran in, and, trembling, fell before Paul and Silas.
He brought them out and said, “Sirs, what must I do to be saved from my wretched spiritual and moral condition?”
They said, “Believe in the Lord Jesus, and you and your household will be saved,”
and he told him the Word of the Lord, him together with his entire household.
At that moment in the middle of the night he took them into his personal care and dressed their wounds. With no further delay he was baptized, he and all who were under his authority,

and he brought them upstairs to his apartment and sat them down at his table and put out a spread of food. He rejoiced with his entire household, as they all arrived at the point where they had faith in God.
Now days went by and the magistrates sent the constables saying, “Let those men out now.”
The jail keeper informed Paul, “The magistrates have sent word so that you can go free. So at this time, leave and go in peace (i.e., go your way free of conflict, duress, or affliction).”

Paul said to the jail keeper, “They beat us in public without a decision handed down from a court proceeding—men who are Roman citizens—threw us in jail—and now they want to kick us out of jail in secret? No—not a chance—have them personally come over and bring us out themselves.”
The constables told the magistrates these remarks; those who heard this became afraid that they’re indeed Roman citizens.
They came and pleaded with them, brought them out, and kept on asking them to leave the city.
After leaving the jail, they went to Lidia’s house and were hosted there, and once they saw comrades, they comforted them, and they finally departed.
After travelling through Amphipolis and Apollonis, they came to Thessalonica, where there was a synagogue.
For three Sabbaths Paul went to the synagogue and approached those who meet in the synagogue, as he was his habit of doing, and reasoned with them from the Scriptures,

going through detail after detail, example after example presenting to them that the Messiah, the Christ, had to suffer and be raised from the dead and that this person Jesus is the Messiah…”The one I’m making known to you.”

Some of them were persuaded and joined in with Paul and Silas, including a great many of the devout, God-fearing westerners (i.e., Greek-speaking near-Jewish converts), and no small number of the leading women.

Overtaken by the passions of jealousy, the Jews went so far as to recruit some hooligans from the hangouts in the middle of town, formed a mob out of them, and proceeded to cause a commotion. After attacking Jason’s house, they started to try to parade them over to the rabble.

Not finding them there, they proceeded to drag Jason and some of the comrades over to the city officials, all the while shouting, “Those guys who’ve ripped through the civilized world like a tornado have arrived here,
the ones Jason has taken in as guests. All these guys engage in activities that violate Caesar’s ordinances, claiming that there’s a different king named Jesus.”
Hearing this disturbed the crowd and the city officials,
and they collected the fine commensurate for the crime from Jason and from the rest of them and released them.
Wasting no time, the comrades immediately sent both Paul and Silas away to Berea during the night, who, after arriving and while being away, went to the synagogue.

Now these people were more open-minded, better educated, and had more sophisticated thought processes than the Thessalonians, being individuals in particular who were totally gung-ho to embrace the Word, who day after day examined the Scriptures to see if all these things which Paul preached were in fact true.
So then, many of them believed, including many of the prominent westerner-women and men—no small number in total.
Now as the Jews from Thessalonica became aware that the Word of God was being proclaimed in Berea, they went there as well to shake up the crowds and to cause them to feel disturbed.
Immediately then the comrades sent Paul away, having him walk until he reached the ocean, while Silas and Timothy remained there.
Those who escorted Paul escorted him until they got to Athens and received an order from Paul destined for Silas and Timothy that they should leave and come to him as quickly as possible.
While Paul was waiting for them to arrive, his spirit was provoked and enraged seeing the city overrun with idols;
so then he kept on reasoning with and disputing with the Jews and the devout sympathizers of Judaism in the synagogue and day in, day out with whoever happened to be in the city square.

Now some of the Epicurean and Stoic philosophers engaged him in a discussion; some proceeded to say, “What point is this dilettante-intellectual here trying to make?”, but others said, “He seems to be a preacher who preaches about weird imps.” They were saying this because he was spreading the word about Jesus and his resurrection,
and they took him and brought him to a meeting of the Areopagus council on Mars Hill, saying, “May we get up to speed on what the new-fangled teaching taught by you is all about?
You see, what you’re filling our heads with is strange, so we wish to understand how this fits into the big picture.”
(Now all Athenians and foreigners who reside in Athens have no time for anything other than talking about or hearing about something novel.)
Paul stood in center-stage before everyone at the Areopagus and said, “Men, Athenians, what I observe of you is that you’re exceptionally devout in every regard;

you see, looking up at your objects of veneration while passing through, I ran across an elevated-altar on which is inscribed, ‘To an unknown God.’ You offer up religious devotion to that which is unknown to you, so I’ll have you know this:
The God who made the world and everything in it—this sky and earth that you see all around you—is a lord who does not dwell in man-made temples,
nor needs the hands-on attendance of healing treatments, as He Himself gives life and breath and everything to everyone and everything,
and in addition made all the nations, races, and ethnic groups that you see living all over the planet out of one person, after delineating arranged seasons and the extent to which they linger,
and made all the nations to seek after God if perchance they might reach out to touch and handle Him and in so doing find Him.
You see, in Him we live and are set in motion and have our existence, as some of your own poets have stated too,“For we are God’s offspring indeed

”So an offspring which gets its existence from God ought not consider the Divine Deity to be comparable to a figure of some sort made with gold, silver, or stone, a craftsman’s sculpture and the reflection of a person’s conceptualization.
So then, having overlooked the epochs of ignorance, at this time God is ordering all people everywhere to go about having a change of heart and of ways,

because a day has been marked on the calendar in which He’s going to judge the civilized world from the perspective of Him being always right and of Him expecting people to do right— judge the world by a man whom He designated, offering assurance to everyone that this is indeed the case by having resurrected him from the dead.”
Once they heard “life-after-death” (i.e. the resurrection of the dead), some began to sneer, but others said, “We’d like to hear from you on this subject again, for sure.”
And with that, Paul left center-stage.
